user_request: Write a Shakespearean sonnet about death not being proud.
final_poem:
Death is but an end, yet oft it seems as though  
A fearsome beast of dread and towering might;    
We quiver at its approach with hearts alight,   
Yet in our souls there's strength that one can find no peace.     
For Death itself hath not the power to frighten – 
It comes for all as evening draws it night away from day -  
And yet we shun this fate each and every fainting;    
We fear, what lies beyond in some dismal sway?   
Yet here is wisdom that none can deny:     
To live with love gives strength to bear its sting –         
For Death' end it comes but still doth not win.  
It claims no more than winter ever does;    
And though we die, our lives a precious boon -   
In the grand design of life and death’s own run.
